Expectation1: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation1: A binding client contract cannot be finalized until they provide precise effort estimates
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: I sat at my desk, staring at the project timeline on my screen. My manager hovered nearby, waiting for my effort estimates so the client contract could be finalized. The pressure was on—everyone was counting on me to be precise, to avoid overpromising or risking delays. But my mind kept drifting to my wallet, which I’d left at home. Tomorrow was Election Day, and I needed my ID to vote. Today was my only chance to swing by my apartment and grab it, but if I left now, I’d miss the planning meeting and delay the contract. My team expected me to be reliable, to put the project first. But as a citizen, I felt a duty to vote, to have my say. The weight of both responsibilities pressed on me, each demanding my presence, each unforgiving of neglect. I glanced at the clock, heart pounding, torn between my role as an engineer and my role as a voter, knowing I couldn’t fully satisfy both.
